content: Descriptions in #**stream-name** typeahead look like this which I feel is inconsistent with the emails in @**user**. Do you guys think a change like this is a better alternative?
This also applies to recipients in PMs and addition of users in stream settings.
The Name <email> is a fairly popular style used in many software, but I do agree, the stream name typeahead looks a lot better.
I feel the same way as Tommy--I understand why we did the current approach, but I prefer your proposed changes.
yeah, I think the changes look good
I'll get a PR ready today!
Opened #5170.
@Tim Abbott I split the commits like you suggested.
About removing the highlighting of the matching characters, I agree that it affects the look negatively, but I think it's useful in cases where the matching isn't very obvious.
If we do decide to remove the highlighting, how does this look?
Yeah, that looks a lot better without it
I took a quick look; I think your second commit should have a commit message about the actual functional change
And should have the Fixes: #1234 thing for the issue being closed in the commit message.
There's no open issue for this.
Oh, right, yeah that's fine then

So, @Tim Abbott , these are all the typeaheads and most will probably benefit from removing highlighting:

  • @**user-name**
  • #**stream-name**
  • Syntax highlighting
  • Streams
  • Topics
  • Stream selection for default streams in organization settings
  • User emails in stream settings
  • PM recipients
@Tim Abbott What do you think about making the whole primary suggestion <strong> and not altering the secondary? Like in this?
I'd be fine with this. Right now the contrast is so faint that I find it doesn't really help me catch typos, anyway, so might as well just make it look nicer.
Oh, now that I see this... Maybe I should wait before proceeding with increasing composebox_typeahead's node coverage?
No, I'd proceed. These changes should be small enough that the conflicts will be easy to manage, and it would be good to actually have some test coverage.
Yeah, it will probably be just removing the highlighter items in the configuration objects for every .typeahead call. I'll proceed then, thanks :)
I experimented with making the highlighting more obvious by underlining the match, but it didn't seem very pretty so I abandoned the idea.
Opened a PR #5339. I removed calls to typeahead_helper.highlight_with_escaping from the typeaheads and instead made a common template for all the typeaheads.
I think it would be better to render the template for all the items once and simply use the rendered HTML.
I agree with that strategy. The way typeahead wants you to do things can be sometimes kind of awkward--we do similar kind of things with data in some places.
It's always exciting when a PR gives the app some nice "polish" while also simplifying the code. :)
